awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Graph-based Probabilistic Cyber Risk Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
Cybersecurity risk analysis is one of the primary tools for managing the consequences of cyber incidents. There are several limitations of the current cybersecurity risk analysis methods. First, cyber risk is often treated as an information technology problem rather than a vital part of enterprise risk management. Another deficiency of the cyber risk analysis methods is the insufficiency of the utilized metrics to support investment decisions. Qualitative metrics and operational terms are often used as cyber risk indicators rather than quantified financial measures that guide investment decisions. Besides these, the lack of quantification of how investments in specific controls change risk level is another limitation of the current cyber risk analysis methods. This project aims to develop a probabilistic quantitative cybersecurity risk analysis model to relate asset-level risk to organizational-level risk and supply chain level risk to respond to the aforementioned deficiencies of the current cyber risk analysis methods. The results from this research enables effective and accurate supply-chain cyber risk assessment, which, in turn, increases economic competitiveness by enabling more effective and efficient mitigation of cyber risks and well-informed cybersecurity investments. The project provides training opportunities for students at different levels and from under-represented groups. Education materials developed in the project will be shared nationally through the National Security Agency supported CLARK repository of cybersecurity learning objects.

The main research problem of this study is what kind of a probabilistic quantitative cybersecurity risk analysis model can be developed to relate asset-level risk to organizational-level risk and supply chain level risk. This project employs probabilistic attack graphs, which are based on known vulnerabilities in computer software and network topologies. The dynamic risk assessment capabilities are augmented in the attack graph using Bayesian Belief Networks. A graph-theoretical functional dependency model is also developed to model the ripple effects of cyber-attacks on enterprise missions to failures in supply-chains. Simulations and sensitivity analysis are conducted on a smart grid testbed to validate the developed risk analysis model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report – NSF Award# 1948261

Project Title: CRII: SaTC: Graph-based Probabilistic Cyber Risk Modeling

Recipient Organization: University at Albany

Project/Grant Period: 04/01/2020 - 03/31/2023

PI: Unal Tatar

This project was awarded in 2019 to the University at Albany to develop a cyber risk model utilizing graph theory. The developed model employs attack graph and impact graph methodologies to calculate the economic risks cyber-attacks to organizations.

The primary outcome of this project is the developed probabilistic quantitative cybersecurity risk analysis model. Using this model, enterprise risk or IT managers can calculate the cyber risk of their organization by relating asset-level risks to organizational-level risks and supply chain level risks. The decision-makers can use this model to (i) identify the critical assets within their network, (ii) identify the likelihood of various cyber attack scenarios, (iii) calculate the economic impact and overall risks caused by cyber incidents, (iv) prioritize vulnerability management efforts, and (v) support decision making, including resource allocation and investments, to improve the resiliency of the enterprise network.

The developed method calculates the likelihood of various cyber incidents using Bayesian attack graph methodology and Common Vulnerability Scoring System metrics. After analyzing the attack propagation, the methodology integrates the findings into the impact propagation model. For the impact propagation analysis, it considers the cascading impacts through internal and external dependencies of an organization. While the internal dependencies consist of dependencies that exist within and among the assets, services, and business processes of the enterprise, the external dependencies are the inter-organizational dependencies at the supply chain level.

Thus far, the project has yielded 8 scholarly journal or conference papers, whether published or under review, along with 8 peer-reviewed abstracts showcased at academic conferences, and a doctoral thesis. These works were collaboratively authored by graduate, undergraduate, and high school students. Highlighting the project's broader reach, NPR’s Academic Minute and the Insurance Journal Magazine have featured our research findings. Such features played a crucial role in enhancing both public and professional understanding of the economic repercussions of cyber threats.

For dissemination purposes, in addition to the publications and presentations, the project team has developed a course module and posted it on the CLARK repository supported by the National Security Agency. Once approved, the course material will be available to all education institutions in the US.

The project offered training and advanced learning experiences for high school, undergraduate, and graduate students. Direct interactions with the project’s principal investigator, serving as their mentor, enriched the students with insights in cybersecurity and cyber risk management. Beyond building the students’ proficiency in technical areas like research, model formulation, and both qualitative and quantitative risk assessments, the initiative also honed their soft skills such as communication, teamwork, and presentation abilities.

As part of our broader impact initiatives, we engaged in various outreach activities. The project’s principal investigator actively participated in the monthly sessions of Girls, Inc. Eureka, a non-profit dedicated to motivating young women towards STEM careers. During these sessions, high school students learned about cybersecurity threats, safe digital practices, and the myriad career prospects in the domain, encompassing potential career trajectories, internships, and pertinent academic programs. Notably, four out of five high school students came on board through Girls Eureka! Furthermore, the PI, along with graduate students, disseminated the research outcomes to wider professional groups, such as the Society of Actuaries, the Society for Risk Analysis, and the Canadian Institute of Actuaries, during their annual conventions.

 


Last Modified: 08/11/2023
Modified by: Unal Tatar
